element.name: en_US
element.field: In this image from Shakespeare's play, Julius Caesar, Brutus watches Cassius point a dagger at his own chest. Text on the print, Cassius: "This is my dagger and here my naked breast." Information on the print: engraved by Hollis, the former from an original picture by Reid, the latter from a daguerreotype by Mayall

element.name: none
element.field: The collector of the prints in this collection was William Appleton Drown (1836-1890) of Philadelphis, PA. The prints were willed to his granddaughter, Elizabeth Phelps Farnsworth, wife of Rhodes College Board of Trustee, Sidney W. Farnsworth, of Memphis,TN. In 1953, Mrs. Farnsworth gave the prints as a gift to the College and it has been stored in the College Special Collections since that time.

element.name: en_US
element.field: Hamlet quotes: "Slanders sir: for the satirical rogue says here, that old men have gray beards; that their faces are wrinkled; their eyes purging thick amber and plum tree gum; and that they have a plentiful lack of wit, together with most weakhams. All of which, sir, though I most powerfully and potently believe, yet I hold it not honestly to have it thus set down; for you yourself, sir, should be as old as I am, if, like a crab, you could go backward."

element.field: The collector of the prints in this collection was William Appleton Drown (1836-1890) of Philadelphia, PA. The prints were willed to his granddaughter, Elizabeth Phelps Farnsworth, wife of Rhodes College Board of Trustee, Sidney W. Farnsworth, of Memphis,TN. In 1953, Mrs. Farnsworth gave the prints as a gift to the College and it has been stored in the College Special Collections since that time.

element.field: Macbeth, 11th century King of Scotland, quotes: "Two truths are told, as happy prologues to the swelling act of the imperial theme." Act 1. Sc. 3. Engraved by Sherratt from the original painting by Tracey. ( Tracey may be John Joseph Tracey, a Dublin, Ireland, painter who lived from 1813 to 1873. source: Benezit, E. Dictionnaire critique et documentaire des peintres, sculteurs...Paris, Librairie GRUND, 1976. Vol. 10:257.

element.name: en_US
element.field: The scene is a chapel in Paulina's house where Leontes and all the court are gathered for the unveiling of the statue. Paulina draws back a curtain to reveal, as the stage direction states, "Hermoine standing like a statue."

element.name: en_US
element.field: Leontes, the king of Sicilia, whose jealousy of Hermione and Polixenes precipitates the tragedy of the first part of the play. This print shows Leontes looking toward Hermione. He is standing full-length with his right hand on a child standing beside him. He has a cape draped across his front and a feather in his cap.
